title: Magnetic Fields and Forces
subject: integrated-science
description: Explore magnetic fields, observe attraction and repulsion between magnets, and map field lines using compasses
objectives: Identify the poles of a magnet (North and South)
Demonstrate that opposite poles attract and same poles repel
Map magnetic field lines using iron filings or compasses
Explain the direction of magnetic field lines

theory.introduction: Magnetism is a fundamental force of nature. Every magnet has two poles (North and South) and creates an invisible magnetic field around it. This field exerts forces on other magnets and magnetic materials.
keyPoints: Magnets have two poles: North (N) and South (S)
Magnetic poles always exist in pairs - you cannot have a single isolated pole
Same poles repel (N-N or S-S repulsion)
The magnetic field is the region around a magnet where magnetic forces act
Field lines show the direction and strength of the magnetic field
Field lines go from North pole to South pole outside the magnet
Field lines never cross each other
Closer field lines indicate stronger magnetic field

magneticFieldProperties.direction: From North pole to South pole (outside the magnet)
magneticFieldProperties.strength: Strongest at the poles, weakest far from the magnet
magneticFieldProperties.visualization: Can be seen using iron filings or detected with compasses
magneticFieldProperties.threedimensional: Magnetic fields exist in 3D space around the magnet

earthsMagnetism.fact: Earth itself is a giant magnet
earthsMagnetism.northPole: Earth's geographic North pole is near the magnetic South pole
earthsMagnetism.southPole: Earth's geographic South pole is near the magnetic North pole
earthsMagnetism.compassBehavior: A compass needle's North pole points toward Earth's magnetic South pole (geographic North)

procedure.instruction: Place two bar magnets on a flat surface, about 30 cm apart
procedure.safety: Handle magnets carefully - strong magnets can pinch fingers

procedure.instruction: Slowly bring the North pole of one magnet near the South pole of the other
procedure.observation: The magnets should attract and pull toward each other

procedure.instruction: Separate the magnets and bring two North poles (or two South poles) together
procedure.observation: The magnets should repel and push away from each other

procedure.instruction: Place one bar magnet on white paper and sprinkle iron filings around it
procedure.tip: Tap the paper gently to help filings align with the field

procedure.instruction: Observe the pattern formed by iron filings
procedure.expected: Filings should form curved lines from North to South pole

procedure.instruction: Place small compasses at various positions around the magnet
Observe the direction each compass needle points
procedure.expected: Compass needles align tangent to the magnetic field lines

procedure.instruction: Draw arrows showing the direction of field lines
procedure.convention: Arrows point from North to South pole

procedure.instruction: Repeat steps 4-8 with two magnets placed end-to-end (N-S)
procedure.observation: Field lines connect the two magnets smoothly

procedure.instruction: Repeat with two magnets placed with same poles facing (N-N or S-S)
procedure.observation: Field lines bend away from each other, showing repulsion

attraction.strength: Force increases as magnets get closer

repulsion.configuration: North near North, or South near South
repulsion.strength: Force increases as magnets get closer

fieldPattern.singleMagnet: Field lines emerge from North pole, curve around, enter South pole
fieldPattern.twoMagnets_opposite: Field lines connect N to S between magnets
fieldPattern.twoMagnets_same: Field lines repel and bend outward between magnets

analysis.lawOfMagneticPoles: Opposite poles attract, same poles repel
fieldLineRules: Field lines go from North to South outside the magnet
Field lines never cross each other
Density of field lines indicates field strength
Field lines are continuous closed loops
analysis.compassBehavior: Compass needle aligns with local field direction. The North-seeking pole of the compass points along field lines toward the magnet's South pole.
analysis.distanceEffect: Magnetic force follows an inverse square law - doubling the distance reduces force to 1/4

applications.description: Use Earth's magnetic field to find direction. Compass needle aligns with Earth's field, with North pole pointing toward geographic North.
Convert electrical energy to mechanical motion using magnetic forces between electromagnets and permanent magnets.
Convert mechanical motion to electricity by rotating magnets near coils of wire.
Use magnetic repulsion to make trains float above tracks, reducing friction and allowing very high speeds.
Medical imaging devices that use very strong magnetic fields to create detailed images of internal body structures.
Hard disk drives use tiny magnets to store computer data. Magnetic patterns represent 1s and 0s.
Store information in magnetic patterns that can be read by card readers.
Use magnets and electromagnets to convert electrical signals into sound vibrations.
Magnetic locks and sensors for doors and windows.

safety: Keep strong magnets away from electronic devices (phones, computers, tablets, TVs)
Keep magnets away from credit cards, ID cards, and magnetic storage media
Handle strong magnets carefully - they can pinch fingers when attracted together
Keep magnets away from people with pacemakers or other medical implants
Don't drop magnets - they can lose their magnetization
Store magnets with keepers (soft iron bars) across the poles to preserve magnetism
Clean up iron filings carefully - avoid getting them in eyes or breathing them in
Wash hands after handling magnets and iron filings

quiz.question: What happens when opposite magnetic poles are brought together?
What happens when two North poles are brought together?
What device uses Earth's magnetic field for navigation?
Where is the magnetic field strongest around a bar magnet?
options: It's strongest far from the magnet

extendedLearning.electromagnets: Electricity can be used to create magnets (electromagnets). When current flows through a coil of wire, it creates a magnetic field. The strength can be controlled by changing the current, and the magnet can be turned on and off.
extendedLearning.magneticDomains: Materials like iron are made of tiny magnetic regions called domains. In unmagnetized iron, domains point in random directions. When magnetized, domains align, creating a net magnetic field.
extendedLearning.curieTmperature: If a magnet is heated above its Curie temperature, the thermal energy disrupts the alignment of magnetic domains, causing the magnet to lose its magnetism.
extendedLearning.temporaryVsPermanent: Soft iron can be temporarily magnetized but loses magnetism quickly. Hard steel retains magnetism for long periods, making good permanent magnets.

vocabulary.definition: The force of attraction or repulsion between magnetic materials
The region around a magnet where magnetic forces act
The ends of a magnet where the field is strongest - North (N) and South (S)
The pulling force between opposite magnetic poles (N-S)
The pushing force between same magnetic poles (N-N or S-S)
Imaginary lines showing the direction and strength of a magnetic field
A device with a magnetized needle that aligns with Earth's magnetic field
A rectangular permanent magnet with North and South poles at opposite ends
Tiny pieces of iron used to visualize magnetic field patterns
A temporary magnet created by electric current flowing through a coil of wire
A small region in magnetic material where atomic magnets are aligned
